title: Workplace Technology (A Special Report)  --- -2-
text:
11: C. While a student at Harvard Business School, Mr. Bricklin, a former software designer, was motivated to create a spreadsheet that ran on an Apple II computer to help with financial analysis. The prevailing pencil-and-paper approach in those days meant that a single change required a lot of recalculation. VisiCalc was a success in the marketplace, but spreadsheets -- and personal computers -- really took off after the release of Lotus 1-2-3.

12: C. In 2009 the addictive devices (dubbed Crackberry by wags) had nearly half the U.S. market (as measured by smartphone operating systems in use). Even as late as September 2013, they reportedly had 85 million subscribers world-wide. But the downfall was swift. By February 2017 market share was essentially zero, Gartner said, even though some people still miss the keyboard.
